publisher.publisher-name: American Association of Teachers of German

title-group.article-title: Berlin and Constance: Two Models of Reform and Their Hermeneutic and Pedagogical Relevance

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1987 The American Association of Teachers of German

abstract.p: The history of literary studies is especially important today as Germanistik takes account of its institutionalization in the university and redefines its disciplinary boundaries. By analyzing the two best-known reform universities, Berlin in 1809/10 and Constance in 1966/67, I show their strikingly similar commitments to notions of scholarship/research, learning, and pedagogy. That these common concerns are based on the influence of hermeneutics is not surprising; the philosophy of Bildung and Wissenschaft central to educational theory for Humboldt in Berlin, as well as for Jauß's and Iser's Rezeptionsästhetik in Constance, is metacritical and encourages reflection on understanding and interpretation.

Peter Renz comments: 'An allen Universitüten der BRD wird Literaturwissenschaft/Germanistik ge- lehrt, allerdings mit z. T. recht erheblichen Unterschieden sowohl in inhaltlicher wie in methodischer Hinsicht. Lehrinhalte, Studienordnungen sowie Möglichkeiten qualifizierter Studienabschliusse sind oft kaum miteinander zu vergleichen. Die bestehenden Schwerpunkte in Forschung und Lehre richten sich meist nach den methodischen wie theoretischen Stand- punkten der dominierenden Lehrstühle an der jeweiligen Universität (z. B. "Rezeptionsis- thetik" an der Universitat Konstanz)" (p. 104)
